study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of early supplementation with a BCAA-enriched formula on short-term postoperative outcomes in older patients undergoing gastric surgery.
results_summary: Early BCAA supplementation was associated with a shorter hospital stay, faster gastrointestinal recovery (defecation and diet initiation), and lesser weight loss compared to routine nutrition.
population_specificity: Older patients (aged 65-80 years) with gastric cancer undergoing curative resection.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated (follow-up until postoperative day 5 for weight loss).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of orally administered branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in slowing disease progression in patients with retinitis pigmentosa (RP).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in visual field progression between the BCAA and placebo groups, though there was an insignificant trend toward slower degeneration in morphological tests. No serious adverse events were associated with BCAA administration.
population_specificity: Patients with retinitis pigmentosa aged 20 years or above.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ultrasound in monitoring muscle status during BCAA supplementation and/or exercise interventions in cirrhosis patients.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation, exercise, or both improved muscle thickness, echo intensity, strength, performance, and nutritional status in cirrhosis patients, with combined intervention showing the best results in Child-Pugh B patients.
population_specificity: 220 liver cirrhosis patients (Child-Pugh B and C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms linking elevated BCAA levels to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, and to summarize the effects of BCAA supplementation or restriction on obesity and insulin sensitivity.
results_summary: The study highlights the disruption of BCAA homeostasis in obesity and insulin resistance, identifies key organs involved in BCAA metabolism, and outlines recent research on systemic modulation of BCAA levels and their impact on insulin sensitivity. It also identifies gaps in understanding the precise mechanisms linking BCAAs to metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in metabolic health and disease, particularly their potential negative effects on aging and related disorders.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that BCAAs might contribute to the deteriorating effects of a protein diet on aging and metabolic disorders, potentially by influencing mTORC1, AMPK, and sirtuin pathways. It highlights tissue-specific metabolic regulation of BCAAs but does not provide conclusive clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Mammals, including humans (review-based, not a specific study population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCAA supplementation affects autophagy and HSP70 responses in PBMCs following intense resistance exercise.
results_summary: The study found no differences in autophagy markers or HSP70 expression between BCAA and placebo groups, indicating BCAA supplementation did not influence these responses. Autophagy markers initially increased post-exercise, while HSP70 response peaked later, but BCAA had no effect on either process.
population_specificity: 20 resistance-trained males (22.3 ± 1.5 yr; 175.4 ± 0.7 cm; 86.4 ± 15.6 kg)
study_duration: 5 days pre-exercise and up to 72 hours post-exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of BCAA supplementation on sarcopenia measures, specifically grip strength and upper limb lean mass, in patients with cirrhosis.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation did not significantly improve grip strength, upper limb lean mass, or other body composition parameters compared to whey protein. No significant differences in physical performance, frailty, hospitalization, or mortality were observed, though fatigue improved across the cohort without between-group differences.
population_specificity: Patients with cirrhosis and reduced muscle strength (median age 58 years, MELD score 14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether co-ingesting a microbial protease mixture with pea protein improves postprandial plasma amino acid concentrations, including branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs).
results_summary: The study found that microbial protease co-ingestion increased total amino acid (TAA) concentrations over 0-5 hours and enhanced early (0-2 h) availability of leucine, BCAAs, essential amino acids (EAAs), and TAAs compared to placebo, though no significant differences were observed for BCAAs over the full 5-hour period.
population_specificity: 24 healthy adults (12 females, 12 males; aged 27 ± 4 years).
effective_dosage: 25 g pea protein isolate (20 g protein, 2.2 g fat) with either microbial protease mixture (P3) or maltodextrin placebo.
study_duration: Single ingestion with postprandial monitoring over 5 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an alginate-encapsulated carbohydrate-protein supplement (ALG) versus a carbohydrate-only control (CON) on cycling performance and plasma branched-chain amino acid levels.
results_summary: The study found that ALG significantly increased plasma branched-chain amino acids during recovery, while maintaining similar cycling performance to CON despite containing less carbohydrate. ALG also elevated plasma glucagon, free fatty acids, and glycerol, but showed lower insulin and glucose responses compared to CON.
population_specificity: 14 men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of BCAA supplementation on muscle damage biomarkers, muscle soreness, and muscle performance post-exercise recovery.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation reduced creatine kinase levels and muscle soreness, particularly with high-dose longitudinal consumption, but had no effect on muscle performance post-exercise recovery.
population_specificity: Not specified (general post-exercise recovery context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate body composition changes after tonsillectomy and explore the potential benefits of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in mitigating muscle mass loss.
results_summary: The study found that BCAA supplementation helped maintain or increase muscle mass in the experimental group, particularly among active individuals, while reducing body fat percentage. The control group experienced significant muscle mass loss, whereas the BCAA group showed stable or improved general health status.
population_specificity: 48 patients undergoing tonsillectomy, divided into control and experimental groups based on activity levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), combined with resistive exercise and other supplements, on pro-inflammatory cytokine levels in sarcopenic patients.
results_summary: The study found that sarcopenic patients had elevated levels of TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6, which declined after a 12-week intervention involving BCAAs, calcium, vitamin D3, and exercise. However, the long-term impact of these interventions remains unclear.
population_specificity: 57 sarcopenic individuals from a geriatric community cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of hemp supplementation (rich in branched-chain amino acids) during resistance training on muscle accretion, strength, and inflammation in trained young adults.
results_summary: Hemp supplementation increased elbow flexor muscle thickness in females and preserved twitch torque and rate of torque development in males under fatiguing conditions compared to soy. Soy supplementation increased muscle thickness in males.
population_specificity: Trained young adults (males: n=22, 29±8y; females: n=12, 30±9y).
effective_dosage: 60 g/d of hemp (containing 40 g protein and 9 g oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate evidence for nutritional interventions, including Branched-Chain Amino Acids, in humans with chronic mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
results_summary: The study identified a lack of interventions involving Branched-Chain Amino Acids in humans with chronic mTBI, with existing studies showing fair to good quality but insufficient data for a meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Humans with chronic (≥1 month) symptomology post-mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the impact of phthalate exposure on gut microbiota and host pathophysiology, including alterations in branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs).
results_summary: The study found that DEHP exposure altered levels of gut microbial metabolites, including BCAAs, leading to cholesterol imbalance or neurodevelopmental disorders. Probiotic supplementation mitigated some phthalate-induced toxicities.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human studies implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the effects of BCAA on muscle protein synthesis (MPS), muscle protein breakdown (MPB), and related molecular signaling pathways in humans.
results_summary: BCAA activates molecular pathways regulating translation initiation, reduces whole-body and MPB indices, and transiently stimulates MPS rates, though the effect on MPS is weaker than with complete protein sources.
population_specificity: Athletes and recreationally active individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight nutritional interventions, including potential roles of micronutrients and nutraceuticals, in managing sarcopenic obesity in cirrhotic patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Branched-Chain Amino Acids but emphasizes the importance of nutritional interventions, protein supplementation, and micronutrients in treating sarcopenic obesity in cirrhotic patients.
population_specificity: Cirrhotic patients with sarcopenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the effectiveness of branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) supplementation in managing hepatic encephalopathy (HE), including minimal HE (MHE) and overt HE (OHE).
results_summary: The review found weak evidence supporting BCAA supplementation for MHE, with two of four studies showing improvement in psychometric testing, but no evidence for its effectiveness in OHE. Adverse effects of BCAA supplementation were few.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatic encephalopathy, including those with hepatocellular carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms behind metformin's effects on branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) regulation during diabetes therapy.
results_summary: The study found that metformin suppresses BCAA uptake in liver cells and cardiac myocytes, particularly by inhibiting the SNAT2 transporter. In humans, metformin attenuated the risk of left ventricular hypertrophy linked to BCAA catabolism and selectively increased plasma BCAA and glutamine levels.
population_specificity: Liver cells, cardiac myocytes, and nondiabetic heart failure patients (from a clinical trial).
interactions: Metformin (attenuated BCAA uptake and affected amino acid homeostasis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of a multi-ingredient supplement containing Branched-Chain Amino Acids (XTEND® Healthy Hydration) on 5-km time trial performance and blood electrolyte concentrations against a carbohydrate-electrolyte beverage (GATORADE®) and distilled water.
results_summary: The study found no differences in 5-km time trial performance between the supplement, GATORADE®, and water. However, the supplement showed favorable effects on blood electrolyte levels and reduced post-exercise cramping compared to the other beverages.
population_specificity: 10 men and 10 women, aged 20-35 years, with BMI ≤ 29 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of BCAAs, L-citrulline, and A-GPC improves exercise performance in trained cyclists.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly improved cycling performance, including time to completion and power output, and may benefit athletic performance requiring lower body strength and endurance.
population_specificity: 30 male trained cyclists (age 43.7 ± 8.5 years)
effective_dosage: 8 g BCAAs, 6 g L-citrulline, and 300 mg A-GPC daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) supplementation as a therapeutic option for liver cirrhosis, particularly in addressing complications like hepatic encephalopathy and sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that BCAAs are decreased in liver cirrhosis patients and their imbalance is linked to complications, but uncertainties remain about the real efficacy, optimal administration route, and dosage of BCAAs supplementation. Several studies were reviewed, but results were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients with liver cirrhosis, including both compensated and decompensated cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify alterations in plasma amino acid concentrations, particularly L-serine and branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), in type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found decreased L-serine and increased BCAA levels in diabetic patients, attributing L-serine deficiency to impaired glycolysis and BCAA elevation to reduced pyruvate and oxaloacetate supply from glycolysis.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) supplementation in improving outcomes for patients with chronic liver disease, particularly cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
results_summary: Long-term BCAA supplementation (≥6 months) improved event-free survival and showed a trend toward improved overall survival in cirrhotic patients, but no clear benefits were found for liver function, nutritional status, or quality of life. No serious side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Cirrhotic patients and those with hepatocellular carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare metabonomic differences between insulin-sensitive (IS) and insulin-resistant (IR) hypogonadal males before and after testosterone therapy (TRT), focusing on the role of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in metabolic pathways.
results_summary: In IR hypogonadism, BCAAs are degraded to activate gluconeogenesis, leading to impaired glucose utilization and increased lipid oxidation, resulting in ketone body production. TRT showed better metabolic restoration in IS patients compared to IR patients, where insulin-related pathways remained impaired.
population_specificity: Male hypogonadal patients with either insulin sensitivity (IS) or insulin resistance (IR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of wheat biscuits supplemented with BCAAs on postprandial glucose response, gastrointestinal hormones, amino acid levels, and appetite sensations in healthy subjects.
results_summary: BCAAs-enriched biscuits (BCAAsB) reduced postprandial glucose and insulin responses compared to conventional biscuits and increased satiety effects. They also elevated postprandial amino acid concentrations.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCAAs supplementation could mitigate muscle damage, soreness, and improve recovery in collegiate basketball players after change-of-direction sprinting.
results_summary: BCAAs supplementation showed negligible effects on interleukin-6 levels but did not significantly reduce muscle damage, soreness, or improve neuromuscular performance or arterial stiffness compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Collegiate basketball players
effective_dosage: 0.17 g/kg BCAAs + 0.17 g/kg glucose, administered before and immediately after exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of oral branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) on prognosis in patients with advanced liver disease, focusing on hepatic encephalopathy, hepatocellular carcinoma, mortality, and liver-related events.
results_summary: Oral BCAAs were effective in preventing hepatic encephalopathy and liver-related events compared to controls, with marginal effects on hepatocellular carcinoma prevention and no significant difference in mortality. The benefits were particularly notable in patients undergoing HCC resection.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced liver disease, including subgroups undergoing HCC resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of BCAA supplementation on recovery following exercise, focusing on cortisol and lactate concentrations.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation significantly reduced cortisol concentration during post-exercise follow-up (≥120 min) and was effective in lowering blood lactate levels in aerobic exercise and trained athletes.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals engaged in high-intensity exercise (146 participants for cortisol, 279 for lactate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of BCAA supplementation on skeletal muscle, glycemic control, and adverse events in elderly individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of BCAA supplementation on skeletal muscle or glycemic control, nor does it mention adverse events.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) on athletic populations, focusing on performance, body composition, and recovery.
results_summary: BCAAs tended to activate anabolic signals but showed negligible benefits on performance and body composition. They attenuated muscle soreness in resistance training but had inconsistent results in endurance sports.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals who train regularly.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocols differed considerably between studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and fish oil (FO) could mitigate muscle damage and improve recovery after eccentric contractions.
results_summary: The BCAA+FO group showed better immediate recovery of peak torque production compared to placebo, while BCAA alone reduced creatine kinase levels and improved range of motion and muscle soreness.
population_specificity: 29 untrained male participants
effective_dosage: BCAA: 9.6 g/day for 3 days before and 5 days after exercise; FO: EPA 600 mg + DHA 260 mg/day for 8 weeks
study_duration: 8 weeks for FO, 8 days total for BCAA (3 days pre- and 5 days post-exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of isolated BCAA supplementation on glucose homeostasis measures (e.g., serum glucose, insulin, HbA1c, HOMA-IR) in individuals with hepatic disorders.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation showed mixed results, with no overall effect on glucose homeostasis. Some studies reported improvements in serum insulin and HOMA-IR, while others showed increases or no changes in glucose-related measures.
population_specificity: Individuals with hepatic disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of essential amino acids (EAA+) and branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) on leucine retention and myofibrillar protein breakdown following home-based resistance exercise.
results_summary: Both EAA+ and BCAAs improved leucine retention compared to a carbohydrate placebo, with no significant difference between them. However, EAA+ was more effective than BCAAs in reducing myofibrillar protein breakdown.
population_specificity: Twelve recreationally active adults (nine male, three female).
study_duration: Single intervention with measurements taken over 5 hours post-supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether BCAA supplementation to a hypocaloric diet affects resting metabolic rate (RMR) and substrate utilization during weight loss.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation did not significantly reduce the decline in RMR compared to standard-protein and high-protein diets, but it increased postprandial fat oxidation after weight loss.
population_specificity: 111 Chinese adults (55 males, 56 females) aged 21-45 with BMI 25-36 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Bacillus coagulans Unique IS-2 supplementation on protein absorption and utilization, particularly branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), in resistance-trained males.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with Bacillus coagulans Unique IS-2 significantly increased absorption of BCAAs (isoleucine, leucine, and valine) and improved exercise performance, particularly in leg press strength and vertical jump power.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained males (21.08 ± 2.84 years)
effective_dosage: 20 g of whey protein powder (15.4 g protein) with 2 billion CFU Bacillus coagulans Unique IS-2 once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein (WP) versus leucine-matched collagen peptides (CP) on muscle thickness and performance following a resistance training program in young adults.
results_summary: The WP group showed greater increases in muscle thickness (vastus lateralis and biceps brachii) compared to the CP group, but both groups had similar improvements in muscle performance (strength and power).
population_specificity: Healthy untrained young adults (n=22).
effective_dosage: 35 g of WP (3.0 g leucine) or CP (1.0 g leucine + 2.0 g free leucine) post-workout and on nontraining days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCAA supplementation could enhance the benefits of a pulmonary rehabilitation program (PRP) for COPD patients by improving muscle function and recovery.
results_summary: The study found that BCAA supplementation did not provide additional benefits over PRP alone in improving exercise capacity, muscle performance, or quality of life. However, muscle oxygenation recovery kinetics worsened in the placebo group but remained unchanged in the BCAA group after PRP.
population_specificity: 60 COPD patients (GOLD 2-3), aged 64.9 ± 8.3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a metabolic signature of minimal hepatic encephalopathy (MHE) in malnourished cirrhotic patients and evaluate its modification with oral nutritional supplements enriched with HMB, a BCAA derivative.
results_summary: The study conducted a post hoc analysis on cirrhotic patients with malnutrition, finding an association between low BCAA levels and hepatic encephalopathy, but did not provide conclusive results on the efficacy of HMB-enriched supplements in the abstract.
population_specificity: Malnourished cirrhotic patients with minimal hepatic encephalopathy.
effective_dosage: 220 mL of Ensure twice a day (exact HMB dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of BCAA supplementation in reducing delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) after exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) in healthy subjects.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation reduced DOMS symptoms 24 to 72 hours post-exercise in trained subjects at doses up to 255 mg/kg/day, particularly for mild to moderate EIMD. However, efficacy was unclear for untrained subjects, higher doses (>255 mg/kg/day), or acute/post-EIMD administration.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects, primarily trained individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCAA supplementation reduces markers of muscle damage and improves performance after strenuous exercise.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 25 studies found that BCAA supplementation showed beneficial effects on muscle damage markers and performance at 24 and 48 hours post-exercise compared to placebo. The studies were rated as fair to excellent in quality.
population_specificity: 479 participants (age 24.3 ± 8.3 years, 26.3% female, height 1.73 ± 0.06 m, body mass 70.8 ± 9.5 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of glycine and branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) on gut barrier function, microbiota, and related biomarkers in malnourished hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact of BCAAs on serum cytokines, appetite mediators, intestinal permeability, or overall microbiota composition, though it reduced the abundance of specific bacteria (L. paracasei and B. dentium).
population_specificity: Chronic hemodialysis patients with malnutrition (plasma albumin <38 g/L or weight loss >5% of dry body weight and low dietary intake).
study_duration: 4 months per supplementation period, with a 1-month washout between crossover.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential of Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) to improve glucose control and body composition in the context of Type 2 diabetes management.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on BCAAs, only mentioning their inclusion as one of several supplements reviewed for potential benefits in managing Type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type 2 diabetes (general mention, no specific subgroup details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify specific parameters associated with BCAA-induced increases in skeletal muscle mass in patients with rheumatic diseases treated with glucocorticoids.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation improved serum creatinine and albumin levels, reduced ammonia and urinary 3-methylhistidine, and mitigated the decrease in plasma amino acid concentrations. Plasma isoleucine, aspartate, and glutamate levels positively correlated with improvement in biceps femoris muscle atrophy.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatic diseases treated with prednisolone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the effect of BCAAs supplementation on plasma muscle damage markers (LDH and CK) and soreness after resistance exercise in trained males.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that BCAAs supplementation had positive effects on lowering plasma markers of muscle damage and subjective soreness after resistance exercise, though efficacy could be moderated by various factors. Pooled data were analyzed using a random-effects model, accounting for heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Trained males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) on nutritional status, physical function, and quality of life in chronic hemodialysis patients with protein energy wasting.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation did not improve lean body mass or other clinical parameters compared to glycine. Unexpectedly, glycine improved fat-free mass index more than BCAA. No significant effects were observed on blood chemistry, plasma amino acids, or other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic hemodialysis patients with protein energy wasting (plasma albumin <38 g/L, dietary intakes <30 kcal/kg/day and <1 g protein/kg/day).
study_duration: 4 months per intervention period, with a 1-month washout between periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of skeletal muscle in BCAA catabolism and how alterations in BCAA levels are linked to liver cirrhosis, diabetes, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
results_summary: The study found that skeletal muscle is central to BCAA catabolism, with decreased BCAA levels in liver cirrhosis due to increased glutamate synthesis, increased levels in diabetes due to metabolic alterations, and inconsistent changes in SIRS due to conflicting metabolic effects.
population_specificity: Patients with liver cirrhosis, diabetes, and disorders exhibiting SIRS (e.g., burn injury, sepsis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effect of multicomponent exercise and BCAAs supplementation on inflammatory markers and albumin levels in frail older adults.
results_summary: The study examined the impact of a 40-week intervention combining exercise and BCAAs on inflammatory markers and albumin in frail older adults, but specific results regarding BCAAs' effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Frail older persons (≥75 years old) living in residential care homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review the current literature on BCAA and leucine supplementation to assess their effects on muscle strength and hypertrophy and identify gaps for future research.
results_summary: The abstract indicates ongoing controversy about BCAA efficacy, with early support based on mechanistic data but mixed results in acute and longitudinal studies. Leucine shows potential for stimulating an acute anabolic response, but practical benefits remain unclear.
population_specificity: Athletes and the general public (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of BCAA supplementation on physical growth and neurological development in term and preterm neonates by comparing different supplementation methods and dosages.
results_summary: No eligible studies met the inclusion criteria, so there was no data to support or refute the effects of BCAA supplementation on neonatal outcomes.
population_specificity: Term and preterm neonates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) in regulating mitochondrial health and their potential benefits for metabolic homeostasis, energy balance, and lifespan.
results_summary: The study found that BCAA-enriched mixtures extended healthy lifespan in elderly mice, promoted mitochondrial biogenesis, and activated antioxidant defense systems in various physiological and pathological conditions. New formulas enriched with Krebs cycle substrates were more efficient than BCAA-enriched mixtures.
population_specificity: Elderly mice and conditions like sarcopenia, muscular dystrophy, liver steatosis, and impaired cognition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a week of BCAA supplementation could improve vertical jump performance in professional male volleyball players.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in countermovement jump performance between the BCAA and control groups over the week, indicating that 21 g of BCAA supplementation did not enhance vertical jump performance.
population_specificity: Male professional volleyball players (n=12).
effective_dosage: 21 g over a week (7 g per day on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of thyroid dysfunction on circulating branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) levels in patients with hypothyroidism.
results_summary: The study found that plasma BCAA levels were lower during hypothyroidism compared to a euthyroid reference population, suggesting a link between thyroid function and BCAA regulation.
population_specificity: 17 patients who had undergone total thyroidectomy for differentiated thyroid carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of the timing of supplemental BCAAs with exercise intervention on physical function in stroke patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of BCAAs, only mentioning the study's focus on timing of supplementation.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a leucine-enriched BCAA dietary supplement (LEBDs) could quickly improve serum albumin, transthyretin, and CRP levels in acute stroke patients with severe malnutrition compared to a standard BCAA supplement (SBDs).
results_summary: The study found that LEBDs led to improvements in transthyretin and CRP levels by the seventh day, while albumin did not improve. In contrast, SBDs showed no improvement in any of the measured markers.
population_specificity: Acute stroke patients receiving enteral tube feeding for at least 7 days.
effective_dosage: LEBDs: 1.44 g leucine twice daily; SBDs: 0.72 g leucine twice daily.
study_duration: 2 days (from the fifth to the seventh day after admission).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether potassium chloride (KCl) supplementation could improve cardiovascular risk by affecting branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) levels in individuals with prediabetes.
results_summary: KCl supplementation significantly reduced BCAA factor and valine levels, indicating potential cardiovascular risk improvement, though reductions in short-chain acylcarnitines were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 26 participants with prediabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing evidence on the effects of Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) supplementation on exercise, focusing on muscle anabolism and weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that BCAA supplementation results were equivocal and not strongly supported by evidence, unlike protein supplements which showed clearer benefits for muscle protein synthesis and recovery.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals engaged in exercise training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of long-term oral BCAA supplementation in patients with advanced liver disease, focusing on liver function and complication reduction.
results_summary: The study found that BCAA supplementation improved MELD and CP scores, increased serum albumin, and reduced cirrhosis-related events and mortality over 24 months compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with liver cirrhosis and Child-Pugh scores of 8-10.
study_duration: 6 months of supplementation, with outcomes tracked for 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding a leucine-rich supplement to a multimodal therapy improved physical function in advanced cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in handgrip strength but no significant improvements in the primary outcome (SPPB), nutritional status, fatigue, or quality of life. The clinical course data indicated the program was safe.
population_specificity: Advanced cancer patients (23 women and 29 men, average age 63.1 ± 10.3 years, BMI 25.4 ± 4.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotic supplementation improves the absorption of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) from pea protein in physically active men.
results_summary: Probiotic administration significantly increased the maximum concentrations (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of BCAAs (valine, leucine, isoleucine) and other essential amino acids, suggesting enhanced absorption without altering the time to reach peak concentrations.
population_specificity: Fifteen physically active men (24.2 ± 5.0 years; 85.3 ± 12.9 kg; 178.0 ± 7.6 cm; 16.7 ± 5.8% body fat).
effective_dosage: 20 g pea protein co-ingested with a multi-strain probiotic (5 billion CFU L. paracasei LP-DG® plus 5 billion CFU L. paracasei LPC-S01) or placebo.
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention, with a 4-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the loss and arterial blood concentration of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) during high-efficiency hemodialysis (HED) and hemodiafiltration (HDF) and assess their metabolic effects on patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study confirmed severe loss of BCAAs (valine, leucine) during HED/HDF, contributing to hypercatabolism and muscle mass loss. Only a few amino acids maintained normal levels, while most, including BCAAs, decreased after 12 months of treatment.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis (10 participants) compared to healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) in regulating brain glutamate and their potential therapeutic application in Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The abstract reviews the importance of BCAA metabolism in regulating glutamate and suggests that BCAA supplementation or restriction may improve cognitive function in neurological diseases, potentially including AD. However, no direct efficacy results are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical application to Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the physiological roles of L-histidine and its derivatives, including potential implications for Branched-Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) in conditions like liver disease.
results_summary: The study noted that HIS supplementation may lead to decreased levels of BCAAs (valine, leucine, and isoleucine) in blood plasma, suggesting it may be inappropriate for patients with liver disease. No direct efficacy outcomes for BCAAs were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with liver disease (indirectly referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential synergistic effects of L-citrulline with other dietary ingredients, including branched-chain amino acids, on vascular function and exercise performance.
results_summary: The study noted that L-citrulline supplementation, including its combination with branched-chain amino acids, increased plasma citrulline and arginine concentrations, but evidence for acute improvements in vasodilation and muscle perfusion was inconsistent. Some studies reported enhanced exercise performance and recovery.
population_specificity: Humans (general exercise performance context, not further specified)
effective_dosage: Not specified for branched-chain amino acids
study_duration: Not specified for branched-chain amino acids

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a commercially available BCAA supplement could reduce perceived exertion (RPE) and improve performance indexes during high-intensity interval training over a 9-week period.
results_summary: The BCAA supplement reduced RPE by 9-21% during recovery and sprint phases, improved time to exhaustion (TTE) and training impulse (TRIMP), and maintained favorable serum tryptophan:BCAA ratios compared to placebo. No differences in dietary habits or glycemia were observed between groups.
population_specificity: 32 untrained, healthy young adults (20 males, 12 females).
effective_dosage: Not specified (taken according to manufacturer's recommendations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and theoretical basis of combining branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and zinc supplementation for managing nutritional deficiency in liver cirrhosis.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation improved survival by correcting amino acid imbalance and restoring albumin synthesis capacity, while zinc supplementation enhanced ammonia metabolism in the liver. The combination therapy addressed both protein synthesis and ammonia detoxification in cirrhotic patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver disease, particularly liver cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to integrate current epidemiological evidence on the association between BCAAs and cardiometabolic disease (CMD) risk factors.
results_summary: Dietary and circulating BCAAs were associated with higher risks of type-2 diabetes and possibly cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, and overweight/obesity, though BCAA supplementation showed some beneficial cardiometabolic effects in certain groups.
population_specificity: Elderly, athletes, and individuals with potential nutritional deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the postexercise aminoacidemia effects of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) and whey protein hydrolysate (WPH) on physically active individuals.
results_summary: Both FPH and WPH significantly increased plasma total amino acids, essential amino acids, branched-chain amino acids, and leucine concentrations postexercise, with no significant differences between the two. FPH was found to be a viable alternative to WPH for rapid postexercise protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Nine physically active subjects (six males and three females).
effective_dosage: 0.25 g/kg of FPH or WPH, administered once postexercise.
study_duration: Blood samples were taken up to 180 minutes post-supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between low dietary protein intake, branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), and their effects on liver lipid accumulation, gut microbiota function, and fatty liver disease.
results_summary: The study found that BCAAs can modulate gut microbiome composition and metabolic activity, potentially influencing protective odd-chain fatty acid (OCFA) and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) production in the liver. Preclinical animal models showed that specific amino acid supplementation, including BCAAs, could ameliorate fatty liver disease induced by low-protein diets.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models (specific species not mentioned) and vulnerable groups in developing countries with dietary protein restriction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) induce insulin resistance in different metabolic tissues and how exercise mitigates these effects.
results_summary: The study found that BCAAs can cause insulin resistance in skeletal muscle, liver, and adipose tissue through the accumulation of toxic catabolic intermediates, but exercise enhances mitochondrial oxidative potential, reducing these intermediates and improving insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Not specified (general metabolic tissues and potential athletes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation, rich in branched-chain amino acids, enhances muscle mass and strength when combined with resistance training in trained individuals.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation increased muscle thickness in some muscles but had no effect on strength. It also increased lean body mass without altering body fat percentage, though no interaction between training and supplementation was found.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men and women aged 18-30 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein versus hydrolyzed collagen supplementation on dietary intake, adiposity, and biochemical markers in overweight women.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation increased nesfatin concentrations and potentially resting metabolic rate, suggesting benefits for body composition improvement, while collagen supplementation appeared ineffective for altering body composition in overweight women.
population_specificity: Overweight women (mean age 40.6 ± 1.7 years, BMI not fully specified).
